SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress established criteria for creating new Federal judicial districts in 1978, including caseload, judicial administration, geography, and community convenience. Caseload considers the number of cases per Federal judge, while judicial administration includes backlog of pending cases hindering effective resolution. The criteria for creating new Federal judicial districts in 1978 include caseload, judicial administration, geography, and community convenience. Geography refers to the accessibility of the central administration, while community convenience relates to better serving diverse populations. The 13 southern counties of New Jersey are part of a substantial criminal district. In fiscal year 2002, the 13 southern New Jersey counties had a high criminal caseload, exceeding that of 32 other Federal judicial districts. For example, the Eastern District of Louisiana had 304 criminal cases, and the District of Connecticut had 251 criminal cases. In fiscal year 2002, the southern New Jersey counties had a substantial civil caseload, with approximately 2,744 Federal civil cases originating in that region. This caseload exceeded that of 61 other Federal judicial districts, with only 32 districts having more civil cases than the southern New Jersey region. In fiscal year 2002, the southern New Jersey counties had a significant caseload, with 2,744 Federal civil cases filed. This exceeded the caseload of 61 other Federal judicial districts, with only 32 districts having more civil cases than the southern New Jersey region. Additionally, the backlog of pending cases in the 13 southern counties of New Jersey necessitates the creation of a separate judicial district. The southern New Jersey region had a high caseload in fiscal year 2002, with 2,744 Federal civil cases filed. The number of pending cases in the Camden vicinage exceeded that of many other Federal judicial districts, indicating the need for a separate judicial district. For example, the Western District of Tennessee had fewer pending cases with 5 judges compared to the Camden vicinage. The Camden vicinage in New Jersey had a high caseload in fiscal year 2002, with 1,400 civil cases and 250 criminal cases pending. The distance between northern and southern regions of New Jersey creates challenges for efficient justice administration. Louisiana's new Federal court district in 1971 also faced distance issues between New Orleans and Baton Rouge. In 1971, Louisiana created a new district court due to travel difficulties between New Orleans and Baton Rouge. New Jersey's District of New Jersey is the fourth most populous Federal judicial district in the United States, with a culturally diverse population inconvenienced by having only 1 judicial district. The population of southern New Jersey counties exceeds that of 69 other Federal judicial districts. New Jersey's District of New Jersey is one of the most populous Federal judicial districts in the United States, with a diverse population. The southern New Jersey counties have a population that exceeds that of 69 other Federal judicial districts. Additionally, New Jersey has a higher population than more than a dozen states with multiple Federal judicial districts. The creation of a new Southern District of New Jersey is being evaluated, and input is being sought from various judicial authorities and the Department of Justice. The attorney represents the Department of Justice in accordance with the established procedure. Establishment of 2 districts in New Jersey: New Jersey divided into Northern and Southern Districts. Northern District includes Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic, Sussex, and Union counties with court held at Newark. Southern District details not provided. The Southern District in New Jersey comprises Atlantic, Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Monmouth, Ocean, Salem, Somerset, and Warren counties. Court for the Southern District is held at Camden and Trenton. The number of judgeships for the Southern District is 7. The District Court of New Jersey is divided into Northern and Southern districts. District judges in the Northern District are assigned to specific counties. The District Court of New Jersey is divided into Northern and Southern districts. Judges in the Southern District are assigned to specific counties in New Jersey. Vacancies in judgeships are first offered to judges from the other district who are in active service, with the most senior judge filling the vacancy. The President appoints a judge to fill the resulting vacancy in the district where the judge left office. Any bankruptcy or magistrate judge in the District Court of New Jersey will be transferred to the Northern District if their duty station is in certain counties, or to the Southern District if their duty station is in other specified counties. Any bankruptcy or magistrate judge in Monmouth, Ocean, Salem, Somerset, or Warren County will be transferred to the Southern District of New Jersey. This transfer does not affect the tenure of the United States attorney, United States marshal, and Federal Public Defender in the District of New Jersey, who will become officials in the Northern District of New Jersey. The President will appoint a United States attorney and marshal for the Southern District of New Jersey, while the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit will appoint a Federal Public Defender for the same district. This section and its amendments will not affect pending cases or jury composition in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey. The composition and service of any jury in the Judicial District of New Jersey on the effective date of this Act will not be affected by this section. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment. Appointments can be made by the President and the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit at any time after enactment. 

SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Sums necessary for implementing this Act and its amendments, including facilities for the District Court for the Southern District of New Jersey, are authorized to be appropriated.
